column1: Deta did not have to be told twice. She said "Good-bye" to Heidi and "Farewell" to the uncle
column2: and started down the mountain. Like steam her excitement seemed to drive her forward
column3: and she ran down at a tremendous rate. The people in the village called to her now more than they had on her way up
column4: because they all were wondering where she had left the child. They were well acquainted with both and knew their history. When she heard from door and windows: "Where is the child?" "Where have you left her
column6: she answered more and more reluctantly: "Up with the Alm-Uncle
column7: —with the Alm-Uncle!" She became much provoked because the women called to her from every side: "How could you do it?" "The poor little creature!" "The idea of leaving such a helpless child up there!" and
column8: over and over again: "The poor little dear!" Deta ran as quickly as she could and was glad when she heard no more calls
